intro: Sorghum saccharatum var. bicolor, commonly known as sweet sorghum, is a tall, robust grass native to tropical and subtropical regions. It is characterized by its thick, juicy stalks that contain high levels of sugar, making it valuable for both livestock feed and biofuel production. The plant typically grows to heights of 2–4 meters and has broad, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowering inflorescence consists of spikelets with small, two-toned florets that range from white to pink. This variety is well adapted to hot, dry climates and requires minimal water, making it a resilient crop in arid environments.
